data.title: Landmarks in Ukraine
data.text:
The name of the city originates from the name of one of the patrol men of Kyiv Princes Askold and Dir- Zhydomyr. The chronicle says that he was the one, who founded Zhytomyr back in 884. Soviet clergy was very unhappy of the name, because of the first part of the word - 'zhyd', which was an abusive name for Jews. The city could have been renamed to Lyonohrad (Lyon = lint), but the attempts were not successful.

Other versions of the ethymology claim that Zhytomyr is a combination of 'zhyto' (rye) and 'myr' (peace), allegedly founded by the tribe of 'zhytychi' who were peacefully growing rye in the area.

Zhytomyr suffered from tatar occupation in 1240, and was subordinated by Lithuanian principality in 1320. Yedygei,the Khan of the Golden Horde demolished the army of Vitautas, the Lithuanian prince in 1399, capturing and ravishing Zhytomyr shortly thereafter. Zhytomyr received Magdeburg's Right in 1444. The city hardly had any peaceful bit of time, being constantly raided by nomads and hordes. The hordes of Mengli-Girey Khan devastated Zhytomyr in 1482. In 1569 Zhytomyr was annexed by Poland in accordance with Lublin Union. The events of the liberation epoch also had some impact on the city. The army of Bohdan Khmelnitsky assailed Zhytomyr Castle; Ivan Bohun won a battle over the 17000 army of Prince Chetvertynski in 1651.

In 1686 Zhytomyr becomes the capital of Kyiv voivodship. 18th century was the century of architectural acquests - Jesuit Monastery and St. Sophia Cathedral. A real cultural and economic boom for Zhytomyr started in 1804, when Volyn Region was annexed by Russia. The city begins flourishing; the city gets the theatre, prominent actors get to play in the new performances - Schepkin, Davydov, Fedotova, Rubinstein. Zhytomyr was visited by Russian Generals Kutuzov and Bagration, poet Denis Davydov, Ukrainian poet & artist Taras Shevchenko. A number of educational institutions and libraries were functioning as well. In 1870es Zhytomyr becomes a telegraph hub in the London-Dehli line. Sergey Korolev, prominent Russian scientist, pioneer of cosmonautics was born in Zhytomyr, as well as Russian writer Kuprin and Ukrainian writer Dovzhenko.

WWII left its ruining impact on Zhytomyr: it was one of the first cities that were bombed on June 22, 1941. The occupation of Zhytomyr by fascist troops started on July 9, 1941. Germans ruined almost every industrial plant, as well as cultural, social, education institutions, hospitals, residential buildings and monuments. Control over Zhytomyr was constantly migrating from Russians to Germans and vice versa. Dozens of industrial factories, transportation faciities, construction and engineering sites were created in the post-war Zhytomyr. Breweries from all around Ukraine are bringing their samples of hop and other beer ingredients to Zhytomyr Hop Research Institute.
